Class Model

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.Observable
      • Model
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    public class Model
extends java.util.Observable
implements java.io.Serializable
    Four In A Row model.

    Current know limitations:

    • Assigning player1 and player2 to have the same name will give unexpected behavior.
    Author:
    Ludde
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

        public void playRow(int col)
             throws InvalidMoveException
        Put the piece in the specified column.
        Parameters:
        col - the column to put the piece in.
        Throws:
        InvalidMoveException - if the column is full.

      • getPlayerName

        public java.lang.String getPlayerName(int index)
                               throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Gets the player name of the specified index.
        Parameters:
        index - of of the player. Valid Index = 1 and 2.
        Returns:
        the player with the specified index.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the index is out of bounds (currently != 1 or 2)

      • setPlayerName

        Sets the player name of the specified index.
        Parameters:
        index - the index of the player who's name should be set.
        newName - the new player name

      • resetGame

        public void resetGame()
        Starts a fresh game. High score is retained.

      • hasWinner

        public boolean hasWinner()
        State checker, to see if a winner exists or the game is still going.
        Returns:
        true if someone has achieved four in a row.

      • getWinner

        public java.lang.String getWinner()
                           throws java.rmi.NotBoundException
        Gets the winner of the current game.
        Returns:
        the winner of the game.
        Throws:
        java.rmi.NotBoundException - if no player has met the win condition.

      • loadModelState

        public void loadModelState(Model model)
        Sets and variables to the new model. Very skeptical that this is the best way to do it. But I wanted to avoid having View variable in the controller. (Which would be needed to set the new Model instance if it was solely done in the controller).
        Parameters:
        model - the model to read all attributes from
